BIOS316
Notes
New module as part of programme review. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
Applied Pharmacology is a key year 3 module, which will be taken by BSc Pharmacology only and is mandatory. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of seminars, workshops, and tutorials. Students will design theoretical pharmaceutical products and take them through a mock pipeline whilst dealing with real world issues, which present themselves along the way. The focus will be on an authentic case-based learning experience with real-world examples of drug discovery/ development used. Authentic real-time problems will be introduced to challenge thinking and instil student clarity of thought and organisation, in order to address sudden, issues in real time. In addition, workshops led by internal and external experts on subjects pertinent to pharmaceutical research and development (including intellectual property, clinical trials, pharmacoeconomics and pharmacovigilance) will be held. Assessment will be via i) a group “elevator-pitch” style short presentation (20%), ii) a lay summary of a research presentation (20%) and iii) a final individual report (60%).
Educational Aims
To equip students with an understanding of the drug development and regulatory process.

To develop skills in communications and problem solving aligned to real world scenarios in pharmaceutical development.

To enhance scientific research interpretation and communication skills.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The pharmaceutical research and development pipeline is multi-stage and requires the interpretation of, and response to, many different forms of information and data. This module will simulate aspects of that pipeline and provide students with an authentic assessment of their ability to apply the knowledge and skills. They will design theoretical pharmaceutical products and take them through a mock pipeline whilst dealing with real world issues which present themselves along the way. Students will meet periodically with teaching staff to discuss the project in tutorial groups and obtain new information pertinent to their project which they will act upon in real time to advance the project. The module will be assessed via i)a group “elevator-pitch” style short presentation, ii) a lay summary of a research presentation and iii) a final individual report . In addition, workshops led by internal and external experts on subjects pertinent to pharmaceutical research and development (including intellectual property, clinical trials, pharmacoeconomics and pharmacovigilance) will be held. Students will attend further research seminars presented by research active staff (academics and postgraduate students).
Outline Syllabus
Students will attend a series of 120mins workshops hosted by both internal and external speakers on subjects which could include, but are not restricted to, the following:
• Intellectual Property
• Drug Safety Assessment
• Clinical Development
• The drug regulatory process
• Drug Repurposing
• Pharmaco-economics and risk benefit analysis
• Pharmacovigilance

A workshop introducing the substantive assessment project will cover the principles of drug target identification and drug repurposing. Student’s will then be required to attend bi-weekly tutorial sessions (6 x 1 hour) with module teaching staff where they will receive further guidance on their group project work and new information they will be asked to incorporate into the project.

Additionally, students will attend a series of 10 research seminars from academics or postgraduate/postdoctoral researchers in the Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutics on subjects which could include, but are not restricted to, the following:
• Drug Safety
• Cancer pharmacology
• Infectious Disease Pharmacology
• Neuropharmacology
• Nanomedicines
• Personalised Medicine

The second assessment will require them to write a lay summary on one of the seminars they have attended. They will however be expected to attend all 10 which will be held in groups of 2-3 talks at a time.

Library resources that are relevant to these topics will be accessible through the module reading list and other key learning resources will be accessible through Canvas, the University’s Virtual Learning Environment. Students are expected to read relevant sections of resources within the reading list and find their own supplementary resources as appropriate (e.g. recent journal articles).
Students will be expected to complete independent reading in preparation for seminars. Student-led workshops will involve group assignments and students will be expected to actively collaborate in preparation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Workshops: these will be 120mins in length and will provide a flipped-classroom learning experience with formative exercises. They will be delivered by both internal and external speakers with expertise in the subject.

Seminars: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus seminars will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.

Tutorials: will be held in the small (4-5 students) project groups with a designated tutor every other week. The purpose of these will be to ensure adequate student progress on the project element and to introduce new information/ data pertinent to the project topic.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments:

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard University of Liverpool (UoL) penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

The first assessment will be an elevator-pitch style presentation which will cover the concept and idea of the novel/repurposed therapeutic target and drug. It is worth 20% of the module. This will be a group assessment (~4-5 individuals per group).

The second assessment will be a lay summary of 300 words which describes and puts into context the research presented at one of the module research seminars. This will be worth 20% of the module.

The third assessment will be a written report in the style of a drug regulatory submission and based on the novel or repurposed drug project running throughout the module. This will be an individual assessment and worth 60% of the module.

All assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing for different audiences is an authentic skill required for further study or employment and delivering short conference style oral presentations is excellent training.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Appraise the fundamental process of drug development and regulation.
 LO2 Identify how drugs can be repurposed for novel applications or indications.
 LO3 Critically appraise and interpret research communications.
 LO4 Choose how to analyse, apply data in order to make decisions on the next steps of a project.
 LO5 Evaluate data and information to inform critical decision making at different stages of the drug development process.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Written and oral communications
 S2 Critical thinking
 S3 Problem solving
 S4 Team working
 S5 Biological interpretation

Applied Pharmacology 2026-27

Org Unit:Biosciences
Level:Level 6

Module Code:BIOS316
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programmes:Pharmacology BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Master of Pharmacology (MBiol) MBiol 2024-25

Replace Instances with Code
BIOS316
Notes
New module as part of programme review. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
Applied Pharmacology is a key year 3 module, which will be taken by BSc Pharmacology only and is mandatory. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of seminars, workshops, and tutorials. Students will design theoretical pharmaceutical products and take them through a mock pipeline whilst dealing with real world issues, which present themselves along the way. The focus will be on an authentic case-based learning experience with real-world examples of drug discovery/ development used. Authentic real-time problems will be introduced to challenge thinking and instil student clarity of thought and organisation, in order to address sudden, issues in real time. In addition, workshops led by internal and external experts on subjects pertinent to pharmaceutical research and development (including intellectual property, clinical trials, pharmacoeconomics and pharmacovigilance) will be held. Assessment will be via i) a group “elevator-pitch” style short presentation (20%), ii) a lay summary of a research presentation (20%) and iii) a final individual report (60%).
Educational Aims
To equip students with an understanding of the drug development and regulatory process.

To develop skills in communications and problem solving aligned to real world scenarios in pharmaceutical development.

To enhance scientific research interpretation and communication skills.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The pharmaceutical research and development pipeline is multi-stage and requires the interpretation of, and response to, many different forms of information and data. This module will simulate aspects of that pipeline and provide students with an authentic assessment of their ability to apply the knowledge and skills. They will design theoretical pharmaceutical products and take them through a mock pipeline whilst dealing with real world issues which present themselves along the way. Students will meet periodically with teaching staff to discuss the project in tutorial groups and obtain new information pertinent to their project which they will act upon in real time to advance the project. The module will be assessed via i)a group “elevator-pitch” style short presentation, ii) a lay summary of a research presentation and iii) a final individual report . In addition, workshops led by internal and external experts on subjects pertinent to pharmaceutical research and development (including intellectual property, clinical trials, pharmacoeconomics and pharmacovigilance) will be held. Students will attend further research seminars presented by research active staff (academics and postgraduate students).
Outline Syllabus
Students will attend a series of 120mins workshops hosted by both internal and external speakers on subjects which could include, but are not restricted to, the following:
• Intellectual Property
• Drug Safety Assessment
• Clinical Development
• The drug regulatory process
• Drug Repurposing
• Pharmaco-economics and risk benefit analysis
• Pharmacovigilance

A workshop introducing the substantive assessment project will cover the principles of drug target identification and drug repurposing. Student’s will then be required to attend bi-weekly tutorial sessions (6 x 1 hour) with module teaching staff where they will receive further guidance on their group project work and new information they will be asked to incorporate into the project.

Additionally, students will attend a series of 10 research seminars from academics or postgraduate/postdoctoral researchers in the Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutics on subjects which could include, but are not restricted to, the following:
• Drug Safety
• Cancer pharmacology
• Infectious Disease Pharmacology
• Neuropharmacology
• Nanomedicines
• Personalised Medicine

The second assessment will require them to write a lay summary on one of the seminars they have attended. They will however be expected to attend all 10 which will be held in groups of 2-3 talks at a time.

Library resources that are relevant to these topics will be accessible through the module reading list and other key learning resources will be accessible through Canvas, the University’s Virtual Learning Environment. Students are expected to read relevant sections of resources within the reading list and find their own supplementary resources as appropriate (e.g. recent journal articles).
Students will be expected to complete independent reading in preparation for seminars. Student-led workshops will involve group assignments and students will be expected to actively collaborate in preparation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Workshops: these will be 120mins in length and will provide a flipped-classroom learning experience with formative exercises. They will be delivered by both internal and external speakers with expertise in the subject.

Seminars: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus seminars will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.

Tutorials: will be held in the small (4-5 students) project groups with a designated tutor every other week. The purpose of these will be to ensure adequate student progress on the project element and to introduce new information/ data pertinent to the project topic.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments:

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard University of Liverpool (UoL) penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

The first assessment will be an elevator-pitch style presentation which will cover the concept and idea of the novel/repurposed therapeutic target and drug. It is worth 20% of the module. This will be a group assessment (~4-5 individuals per group).

The second assessment will be a lay summary of 300 words which describes and puts into context the research presented at one of the module research seminars. This will be worth 20% of the module.

The third assessment will be a written report in the style of a drug regulatory submission and based on the novel or repurposed drug project running throughout the module. This will be an individual assessment and worth 60% of the module.

All assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing for different audiences is an authentic skill required for further study or employment and delivering short conference style oral presentations is excellent training.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Appraise the fundamental process of drug development and regulation.

 LO3 Critically appraise and interpret research communications.
 LO4 Choose how to analyse, apply data in order to make decisions on the next steps of a project.
 LO5 Evaluate data and information to inform critical decision making at different stages of the drug development process.
Skills

Notes
New module as part of programme review. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
Applied Pharmacology is a key year 3 module, which will be taken by BSc Pharmacology only and is mandatory. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of seminars, workshops, and tutorials. Students will design theoretical pharmaceutical products and take them through a mock pipeline whilst dealing with real world issues, which present themselves along the way. The focus will be on an authentic case-based learning experience with real-world examples of drug discovery/ development used. Authentic real-time problems will be introduced to challenge thinking and instil student clarity of thought and organisation, in order to address sudden, issues in real time. In addition, workshops led by internal and external experts on subjects pertinent to pharmaceutical research and development (including intellectual property, clinical trials, pharmacoeconomics and pharmacovigilance) will be held. Assessment will be via i) a group “elevator-pitch” style short presentation (20%), ii) a lay summary of a research presentation (20%) and iii) a final individual report (60%).
Educational Aims
To equip students with an understanding of the drug development and regulatory process.

To develop skills in communications and problem solving aligned to real world scenarios in pharmaceutical development.

To enhance scientific research interpretation and communication skills.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The pharmaceutical research and development pipeline is multi-stage and requires the interpretation of, and response to, many different forms of information and data. This module will simulate aspects of that pipeline and provide students with an authentic assessment of their ability to apply the knowledge and skills. They will design theoretical pharmaceutical products and take them through a mock pipeline whilst dealing with real world issues which present themselves along the way. Students will meet periodically with teaching staff to discuss the project in tutorial groups and obtain new information pertinent to their project which they will act upon in real time to advance the project. The module will be assessed via i)a group “elevator-pitch” style short presentation, ii) a lay summary of a research presentation and iii) a final individual report . In addition, workshops led by internal and external experts on subjects pertinent to pharmaceutical research and development (including intellectual property, clinical trials, pharmacoeconomics and pharmacovigilance) will be held. Students will attend further research seminars presented by research active staff (academics and postgraduate students).
Outline Syllabus
Students will attend a series of 120mins workshops hosted by both internal and external speakers on subjects which could include, but are not restricted to, the following:
• Intellectual Property
• Drug Safety Assessment
• Clinical Development
• The drug regulatory process
• Drug Repurposing
• Pharmaco-economics and risk benefit analysis
• Pharmacovigilance

A workshop introducing the substantive assessment project will cover the principles of drug target identification and drug repurposing. Student’s will then be required to attend bi-weekly tutorial sessions (6 x 1 hour) with module teaching staff where they will receive further guidance on their group project work and new information they will be asked to incorporate into the project.

Additionally, students will attend a series of 10 research seminars from academics or postgraduate/postdoctoral researchers in the Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutics on subjects which could include, but are not restricted to, the following:
• Drug Safety
• Cancer pharmacology
• Infectious Disease Pharmacology
• Neuropharmacology
• Nanomedicines
• Personalised Medicine

The second assessment will require them to write a lay summary on one of the seminars they have attended. They will however be expected to attend all 10 which will be held in groups of 2-3 talks at a time.

Library resources that are relevant to these topics will be accessible through the module reading list and other key learning resources will be accessible through Canvas, the University’s Virtual Learning Environment. Students are expected to read relevant sections of resources within the reading list and find their own supplementary resources as appropriate (e.g. recent journal articles).
Students will be expected to complete independent reading in preparation for seminars. Student-led workshops will involve group assignments and students will be expected to actively collaborate in preparation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Workshops: these will be 120mins in length and will provide a flipped-classroom learning experience with formative exercises. They will be delivered by both internal and external speakers with expertise in the subject.

Seminars: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus seminars will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.

Tutorials: will be held in the small (4-5 students) project groups with a designated tutor every other week. The purpose of these will be to ensure adequate student progress on the project element and to introduce new information/ data pertinent to the project topic.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments:

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard University of Liverpool (UoL) penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

The first assessment will be an elevator-pitch style presentation which will cover the concept and idea of the novel/repurposed therapeutic target and drug. It is worth 20% of the module. This will be a group assessment (~4-5 individuals per group).

The second assessment will be a lay summary of 300 words which describes and puts into context the research presented at one of the module research seminars. This will be worth 20% of the module.

The third assessment will be a written report in the style of a drug regulatory submission and based on the novel or repurposed drug project running throughout the module. This will be an individual assessment and worth 60% of the module.

All assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing for different audiences is an authentic skill required for further study or employment and delivering short conference style oral presentations is excellent training.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Appraise the fundamental process of drug development and regulation.
 LO2 Identify how drugs can be repurposed for novel applications or indications.
 LO3 Critically appraise and interpret research communications.
 LO4 Choose how to analyse, apply data in order to make decisions on the next steps of a project.
 LO5 Evaluate data and information to inform critical decision making at different stages of the drug development process.
